description: From Middle English spire, spyre, spier, spir, from Old English spīr, from Proto-Germanic *spīrō, *spīrǭ (“peak; point; tip; stalk”). Cognate with Dutch spier, German Low German Spier, German Spier, Spiere, Danish spir, Norwegian spir and spire, Swedish spira, Icelandic spíra.

entries.meaning: (now rare) The stalk or stem of a plant. [from 10th c.]
A young shoot of a plant; a spear. [from 14th c.]
Any of various tall grasses, rushes, or sedges, such as the marram, the reed canary-grass, etc.
A sharp or tapering point. [from 16th c.]
(architecture) A tapering structure built on a roof or tower, especially as one of the central architectural features of a church or cathedral roof. [from 16th c.]
examples: The spire of the church rose high above the town.

entries.meaning: The top, or uppermost point, of anything; the summit. [from 17th c.]
(mining) A tube or fuse for communicating fire to the charge in blasting.

verbs.description: spire (third-person singular simple present spires, present participle spiring, simple past and past participle spired)

entries.meaning: (of a seed, plant etc.) to sprout, to send forth the early shoots of growth; to germinate. [from 14th c.]
examples: It is not so apt to spire up as the other sorts, being more inclined to branch into arms.

entries.meaning: To grow upwards rather than develop horizontally. [from 14th c.]

description: From Old French spirer, and its source, Latin spīrō (“to breathe”).

verbs.description: spire (third-person singular simple present spires, present participle spiring, simple past and past participle spired)

entries.meaning: One of the sinuous foldings of a serpent or other reptile; a coil. [from 16th c.]
(geometry) The part of a spiral generated in one revolution of the straight line about the pole.
